prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the required sensitivity by the line strength of C2H(1-0), which represents the weakest targeted transitions in our setup, from observations with the Onsala Space Observatory (OSO) from Woods et al. (2003). For RW LMi, the observed peak line flux of C2H(1-0) is 1.2 Jy. We assume a ring-like emission structure of 5.1 arcsec radius and 0.7 arcsec width (sizes distance-scaled relative to IRC+10216) to determine the flux density per synthesized beam (for an angular resolution of 0.7 arcsec), which is 10.1 mJy per beam. Given the uncertainties in distance, ring thickness and molecular excitation, we aim a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of at least 5, which results in a requested rms of 2.0 mJy/beam for RW LMi. The rms is given relative to selected spectral resolution of 1.1 MHz, which corresponds to velocity channel widths of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s, to resolve potential features in the line profiles of typical widths of about 35 km/s with sufficient SNR for a clear detection.

The spectral resolution is chosen to about 3.3 - 3.8 km/s to have a resolution per FWHM of the order of 10 for each spectral line of typical width of about 35 km/s, for RW LMi (Loup et al. 1993). We average over every 2 channels to lower the data rate.

We expect the emission of carbon chains to be concentrated in shells around the star with an intrinsic radius and width close to what is seen for IRC+10216. The molecular shells around IRC+10216 have an observed radius of 15 arcsec with a typical width of 2 arcsec. We scale the expected angular sizes of RW LMi to those of IRC+10216 relative to their distances of 0.38 and 0.13 kpc, respectively, which are uncertain to a factor of 2. We need an angular resolution of at least the apparent size of the ring width to detect/probe the radial position and the emission strengths of the observed molecular species. To compensate for the uncertainty of the distances and to have some tolerance on the actually observed angular scales, we choose the largest angular scale to be about two times the calculated distance-scaled extent of the molecular shell. For RW LMi, we request an angular resolution of 0.7 arcsec and give 20 arcsec as the largest angular scale.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, because experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity. The spectral resolution of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s is required to resolve potential features in the line profiles. Given that the FWZP line widths of all our target stars are greater than about 30 km/s, it is also adequate.

We estimate the required sensitivity by the line strength of C2H(1-0), which represents the weakest targeted transitions in our setup, from observations with the Swedish-ESO Submillimetre Telescope (SEST) from Woods et al. (2003). For II Lup, the observed peak line flux of C2H(1-0) is 2.6 Jy. We assume a ring-like emission structure of 3.2 arcsec radius and 0.4 arcsec width (sizes distance-scaled relative to IRC+10216) to determine the flux density per synthesized beam (for an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec), which is 21.96 mJy per beam. Given the uncertainties in distance, ring thickness and molecular excitation, we aim a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of at least 5, which results in a requested rms of 4.4 mJy/beam for II Lup. The rms is given relative to selected spectral resolution of 1.1 MHz, which corresponds to velocity channel widths of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s, to resolve potential features in the line profiles of typical widths of about 47 km/s with sufficient SNR for a clear detection.

The spectral resolution is chosen to about 3.3 - 3.8 km/s to have a resolution per FWHM of the order of 10 for each spectral line of typical width of about 47 km/s, for II Lup (Loup et al 1993). We average over every 2 channels to lower the data rate.

We expect the emission of carbon chains to be concentrated in shells around the star with an intrinsic radius and width close to what is seen for IRC+10216. The molecular shells around IRC+10216 have an observed radius of 15 arcsec with a typical width of 2 arcsec. We scale the expected angular sizes of II Lup to those of IRC+10216 relative to their distances of 0.60 and 0.13 kpc, respectively, which are uncertain to a factor of 2. We need an angular resolution of at least the apparent size of the ring width to detect/probe the radial position and the emission strengths of the observed molecular species. To compensate for the uncertainty of the distances and to have some tolerance on the actually observed angular scales, we choose the largest angular scale to be about two times the calculated distance-scaled extent of the molecular shell. For II Lup, we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec and give 20 arcsec as the largest angular scale.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, because experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity. The spectral resolution of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s is required to resolve potential features in the line profiles. Given that the FWZP line widths of all our target stars are greater than about 30 km/s, it is also adequate.

We estimate the required sensitivity by the line strength of C2H(1-0), which represents the weakest targeted transitions in our setup, from observations with the Swedish-ESO Submillimetre Telescope (SEST) from Woods et al. (2003). For IRC+10216, the observed peak line flux of C2H(1-0) is 10.5 Jy. We assume a ring-like emission structure of 15 arcsec radius and 2.0 arcsec width to determine the flux density per synthesized beam (for an angular resolution of 2.0 arcsec), which is 87.83 mJy per beam. Given the uncertainties in distance, ring thickness and molecular excitation, we aim a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of at least 5, which results in a requested rms of 17.6 mJy/beam for IRC+10216. The rms is given relative to selected spectral resolution of 1.1 MHz, which corresponds to velocity channel widths of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s, to resolve potential features in the line profiles of typical widths of about 30 km/s with sufficient SNR for a clear detection.

The spectral resolution is chosen to about 3.3 - 3.8 km/s to have a resolution per FWHM of the order of 10 for each spectral line of typical width of about 30 km/s, for IRC+10216 (Loup et al 1993). We average over every 2 channels to lower the data rate.

We expect the emission of carbon chains to be concentrated in shells around the star with a similar intrinsic radius for all sources. The molecular shells around IRC+10216 have an observed radius of 15 arcsec with a typical width of 2 arcsec. We need an angular resolution of at least the apparent size of the ring width to detect/probe the radial position and the emission strengths of the observed molecular species. To compensate for the uncertainty of the distance to a factor of 2 and to have some tolerance on the actually observed angular scales, we choose the largest angular scale to be about two times the expected extent of the molecular shell. For IRC+10216, this results in a largest angular scale of 60 arcsec, which is larger than the maximum recoverable scale of the 12m-array, so we need to add observations with the 7m-ACA to be sensitive to the extended emission.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, because experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity. The spectral resolution of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s is required to resolve potential features in the line profiles. Given that the FWZP line widths of all our target stars are greater than about 30 km/s, it is also adequate.

We estimate the required sensitivity by the line strength of C2H(1-0), which represents the weakest targeted transitions in our setup, from observations with the Swedish-ESO Submillimetre Telescope (SEST) from Woods et al. (2003). For V358 Lup, the observed peak line flux of C2H(1-0) is 0.81 Jy. We assume a ring-like emission structure of 2.9 arcsec radius and 0.4 arcsec width (sizes distance-scaled relative to IRC+10216) to determine the flux density per synthesized beam (for an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec), which is 6.76 mJy per beam. Given the uncertainties in distance, ring thickness and molecular excitation, we aim a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of at least 5, which results in a requested rms of 1.4 mJy/beam for V358 Lup. The rms is given relative to selected spectral resolution of 1.1 MHz, which corresponds to velocity channel widths of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s, to resolve potential features in the line profiles of typical widths of about 41 km/s with sufficient SNR for a clear detection.

The spectral resolution is chosen to about 3.3 - 3.8 km/s to have a resolution per FWHM of the order of 10 for each spectral line of typical width of about 41 km/s, for V358 Lup (Loup et al 1993). We average over every 2 channels to lower the data rate.

We expect the emission of carbon chains to be concentrated in shells around the star with an intrinsic radius and width close to what is seen for IRC+10216. The molecular shells around IRC+10216 have an observed radius of 15 arcsec with a typical width of 2 arcsec. We scale the expected angular sizes of V358 Lup to those of IRC+10216 relative to their distances of 0.67 and 0.13 kpc, respectively, which are uncertain to a factor of 2. We need an angular resolution of at least the apparent size of the ring width to detect/probe the radial position and the emission strengths of the observed molecular species. To compensate for the uncertainty of the distances and to have some tolerance on the actually observed angular scales, we choose the largest angular scale to be about two times the calculated distance-scaled extent of the molecular shell. For V358 Lup, we request an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec and give 20 arcsec as the largest angular scale.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, because experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity. The spectral resolution of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s is required to resolve potential features in the line profiles. Given that the FWZP line widths of all our target stars are greater than about 30 km/s, it is also adequate.

We estimate the required sensitivity by the line strength of C2H(1-0), which represents the weakest targeted transitions in our setup, observed in IRC+10216 from Woods et al. (2003) and scaled by the relative distance to CQ Pyx. The estimated peak line flux of C2H(1-0) then is 1.01 Jy. We assume a ring-like emission structure of 4.6 arcsec radius and 0.6 arcsec width (sizes distance-scaled relative to IRC+10216) to determine the flux density per synthesized beam (for an angular resolution of 0.6 arcsec), which is 8.4 mJy per beam. Given the uncertainties in distance, ring thickness and molecular excitation, we aim a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of at least 5, which results in a requested rms of 1.7 mJy/beam for CQ Pyx. The rms is given relative to selected spectral resolution of 1.1 MHz, which corresponds to velocity channel widths of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s, to resolve potential features in the line profiles of typical widths of about 27 km/s with sufficient SNR for a clear detection.

The spectral resolution is chosen to about 3.3 - 3.8 km/s to have a resolution per FWHM of the order of 10 for each spectral line of typical width of about 27 km/s, for CQ Pyx (Loup et al 1993). We average over every 2 channels to lower the data rate.

We expect the emission of carbon chains to be concentrated in shells around the star with an intrinsic radius and width close to what is seen for IRC+10216. The molecular shells around IRC+10216 have an observed radius of 15 arcsec with a typical width of 2 arcsec. We scale the expected angular sizes of CQ Pyx to those of IRC+10216 relative to their distances of 0.42 and 0.13 kpc, respectively, which are uncertain to a factor of 2. We need an angular resolution of at least the apparent size of the ring width to detect/probe the radial position and the emission strengths of the observed molecular species. To compensate for the uncertainty of the distances and to have some tolerance on the actually observed angular scales, we choose the largest angular scale to be about two times the calculated distance-scaled extent of the molecular shell. For CQ Pyx, we request an angular resolution of 0.6 arcsec and give 20 arcsec as the largest angular scale.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, because experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity. The spectral resolution of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s is required to resolve potential features in the line profiles. Given that the FWZP line widths of all our target stars are greater than about 30 km/s, it is also adequate.

We estimate the required sensitivity by the line strength of C2H(1-0), which represents the weakest targeted transitions in our setup, observed in IRC+10216 from Woods et al. (2003) and scaled by the relative distance to V Hya and U Hya. The estimated peak line flux of C2H(1-0) then are 1.64 and 1.45 Jy, respectively. We assume a ring-like emission structure of 5.9 and 5.6 arcsec radius, resp., and 0.7 arcsec width each, (sizes distance-scaled relative to IRC+10216) to determine the flux density per synthesized beam (for an angular resolution of 0.7 arcsec), which is 12.8 and 12.1 mJy per beam, resp. Given the uncertainties in distance, ring thickness and molecular excitation, we aim a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of at least 5, which results in a requested rms of 2.5 mJy/beam for V Hya and U Hya each. The rms is given relative to selected spectral resolution of 1.1 MHz, which corresponds to velocity channel widths of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s, to resolve potential features in the line profiles of typical widths of about 16 - 42 km/s with sufficient SNR for a clear detection.

The spectral resolution is chosen to about 3.3 - 3.8 km/s to have a resolution per FWHM of the order of 10 for each spectral line of typical width of about 16 - 42 km/s, for U Hya and V Hya (Loup et al 1993). We average over every 2 channels to lower the data rate.

We expect the emission of carbon chains to be concentrated in shells around the star with an intrinsic radius and width close to what is seen for IRC+10216. The molecular shells around IRC+10216 have an observed radius of 15 arcsec with a typical width of 2 arcsec. We scale the expected angular sizes of V Hya and U Hya to those of IRC+10216 relative to their distances of 0.33 and 0.35 kpc, and 0.13 kpc, respectively, which are uncertain to a factor of 2. We need an angular resolution of at least the apparent size of the ring width to detect/probe the radial position and the emission strengths of the observed molecular species. To compensate for the uncertainty of the distances and to have some tolerance on the actually observed angular scales, we choose the largest angular scale to be about two times the calculated distance-scaled extent of the molecular shell. For V Hya and U Hya, we request an angular resolution of 0.7 arcsec and give 25 arcsec as the largest angular scale.

We request use of the full 4 x 1.875-GHz bandwidth, because experience has shown that at the low flux levels we are aiming at, unexpected interesting lines can be detected. Employing the maximal available bandwidth thus enables continuum detection and greatly increases serendipity. The spectral resolution of 3.3 - 3.8 km/s is required to resolve potential features in the line profiles. Given that the FWZP line widths of all our target stars are greater than about 30 km/s, it is also adequate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: IRC+10216 is a well-studied carbon-rich star in the envelope of which, more than 80 molecules have been discovered by various line-surveys. Due to limited sensitivity, it has so far not been possible to carry out similar ranges of surveys of other carbon stars, hence we do not know how truly representative IRC+10216 is in its chemically rich composition. We propose to observe transitions of several carbon-bearing molecules, that are key stepping stones in the chemical reaction network, in the circumstellar envelopes of a sample of 7 carbon stars with different mass-loss rates and distances with ALMA in compact configuration. Comparing the spatial distributions of these molecules, and associate with stellar properties, will constrain the photochemical synthesis of longer carbon chain-bearing species in the outer envelope of carbon stars and will classify IRC+10216 within these. The proposed observations will provide crucial data towards the testing and refinement of our understanding of carbon chain chemistry for application in chemical models.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
